Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the truck screeched to a halt,
one of its containers slid off, hit an approaching Prius 
and spilled its contents. Those contents happened to be thousands
of kilograms of live hagfish, also known as slime eels. The result of this 2017 car accident 
was an absolute mess: the highway was littered 
with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime that took 
the fire department 7 hours to clear. Astonishingly good looks aside, the standout strength of all hagfishes
is their slime. In fact, they’re probably 
Earth’s slimiest animals. But why be so slimy? Watch and learn. This hagfish has detected a dead fish
using its keen sense of smell and the tastebud-like organs 
dotting its skin. Revealing imposing rows of toothlike
structures, it takes the first bite. A shark glides on to the scene
and suddenly lunges. Being caught in the shark’s powerful jaws
may seem like a guaranteed death sentence, but the hagfish has some tricks 
up its sleeve. The shark’s teeth clench down
but there are no bones to crush— only flexible cartilage. And because the hagfish’s skin is so 
loosely attached to the rest of its body, the pressure from the bite causes the hagfish’s essential organs
to slip out of the way, avoiding damage. This is where being a noodle 
in a baggy wetsuit really pays off. Meanwhile, the hagfish also actively
repels the shark by spewing a stupendous supply of slime. Around a hundred slime glands
line each side of the hagfish’s body. Within them are mucus and thread cells. The mucus cells are packed with hundreds
of vesicles of condensed mucus while each thread cell contains 
an intricately coiled protein fiber. The hagfish contracts the muscles
surrounding some of its slime glands, causing the cells to eject their contents
into the seawater. In a fraction of a second, 
the mucus vesicles swell and burst, and the protein fibers unravel. Together, they expand to 10,000 times
their original volume, instantly creating liters of slime. Because the substance is composed of mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine 
and strong silk-like fibers, the slime is incredibly soft yet tough. It lodges in the shark’s delicate gills, and as the shark chokes 
and tries to clear the slime, it releases the hagfish. Now, the hagfish is free 
from the jaws of death. But it’s in a dilemma of its own doing, trapped in a cloud of its own
suffocating slime. So what does it do? Well, it ties itself in a knot, of course. Starting at its tail 
and passing its body through, the hagfish effectively wipes away
its own slime. Apparently unfazed by the whole encounter, it returns to its meal. When it gets to a tougher part 
of the carcass... Voila! The hagfish ties itself 
in yet another knot to gain leverage and yank off the meat. The hagfish’s slime is so remarkable
that people are trying to emulate it. Currently, a lot of athletic 
and safety gear is made from non-renewable
petroleum-based fibers. But hagfish slime threads rival 
the properties of materials like nylon. And fibers modeled after those 
in hagfish slime may present a much more sustainable alternative. Meanwhile, hagfish slime is also being 
explored in military contexts as a non-lethal weapon that could be used
to stop boats by sliming up their propellers. In addition to mastering
the art of slime and knot-tying, hagfish have four little hearts and can survive 36 hours 
without oxygen unscathed. Oh, and they also clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients 
in the deep sea. Proto-hagfish were navigating
the ocean’s depths more than 300 million years ago— before dinosaurs roamed 
and back when Pangea was still a thing. Having persisted through multiple
mass extinction events, hagfish have just about seen it all. And it would appear that they’re still
having a wonderful slime.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why is hagfish slime tough to remove from a predator’s gills or a Prius?
Options: A. It is mostly composed of water, B. It is very slimy , C. It contains cartilage, D. It contains a network of fibers
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the result of the 2017 car accident involving a truck carrying live hagfish? Options: A. The highway was littered with dead fish and debris., B. The highway was littered with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime., C. The truck driver was injured and taken to the hospital., D. The accident caused a massive traffic jam. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the standout strength of all hagfishes? Options: A. Their ability to detect dead fish using their keen sense of smell., B. Their imposing rows of toothlike structures., C. Their slime., D. Their ability to survive without oxygen for 36 hours. Correct Option: C
Question 3: How do hagfish protect themselves from predators like sharks? Options: A. By using their toothlike structures to defend themselves., B. By releasing a cloud of slime that lodges in the shark's gills., C. By swimming away quickly., D. By using their four little hearts to pump more blood. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the composition of hagfish slime? Options: A. Mucus and water., B. Mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine and strong silk-like fibers., C. Protein fibers and water., D. Mucus and toothlike structures. Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why are researchers interested in emulating hagfish slime? Options: A. Because it is incredibly soft and fragile., B. Because it is incredibly soft yet tough and could be used to create sustainable materials., C. Because it is only found in hagfish., D. Because it is not useful for any practical applications. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one potential military application of hagfish slime? Options: A. As a lethal weapon to kill enemy soldiers., B. As a non-lethal weapon to stop boats by sliming up their propellers., C. As a tool for espionage., D. As a way to protect against chemical attacks. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How do hagfish clean themselves after releasing slime? Options: A. By swimming through a school of fish to wipe away the slime., B. By using their toothlike structures to scrape off the slime., C. By tying themselves in a knot to wipe away the slime., D. By using their four little hearts to pump more blood. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is another unique feature of hagfish besides their slime? Options: A. Their ability to survive without oxygen for 36 hours., B. Their four little hearts., C. Their ability to tie themselves in knots., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What role do hagfish play in the ecosystem? Options: A. They are apex predators and regulate the population of other sea creatures., B. They clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients in the deep sea., C. They are prey for many other sea creatures and help to support the food chain., D. They have no significant role in the ecosystem. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How long have hagfish been present on Earth? Options: A. For over 100 million years., B. For over 300 million years., C. For over 500 million years., D. For over 1 billion years. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question is about the composition of hagfish slime, which directly relates to why the slime is tough to remove from a predator's gills or a Prius. The correct option in Question 4 (B. Mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine and strong silk-like fibers) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (D. It contains a network of fibers), as both mention the presence of fibers that contribute to the slime's toughness.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the truck screeched to a halt,
one of its containers slid off, hit an approaching Prius 
and spilled its contents. Those contents happened to be thousands
of kilograms of live hagfish, also known as slime eels. The result of this 2017 car accident 
was an absolute mess: the highway was littered 
with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime that took 
the fire department 7 hours to clear. Astonishingly good looks aside, the standout strength of all hagfishes
is their slime. In fact, they’re probably 
Earth’s slimiest animals. But why be so slimy? Watch and learn. This hagfish has detected a dead fish
using its keen sense of smell and the tastebud-like organs 
dotting its skin. Revealing imposing rows of toothlike
structures, it takes the first bite. A shark glides on to the scene
and suddenly lunges. Being caught in the shark’s powerful jaws
may seem like a guaranteed death sentence, but the hagfish has some tricks 
up its sleeve. The shark’s teeth clench down
but there are no bones to crush— only flexible cartilage. And because the hagfish’s skin is so 
loosely attached to the rest of its body, the pressure from the bite causes the hagfish’s essential organs
to slip out of the way, avoiding damage. This is where being a noodle 
in a baggy wetsuit really pays off. Meanwhile, the hagfish also actively
repels the shark by spewing a stupendous supply of slime. Around a hundred slime glands
line each side of the hagfish’s body. Within them are mucus and thread cells. The mucus cells are packed with hundreds
of vesicles of condensed mucus while each thread cell contains 
an intricately coiled protein fiber. The hagfish contracts the muscles
surrounding some of its slime glands, causing the cells to eject their contents
into the seawater. In a fraction of a second, 
the mucus vesicles swell and burst, and the protein fibers unravel. Together, they expand to 10,000 times
their original volume, instantly creating liters of slime. Because the substance is composed of mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine 
and strong silk-like fibers, the slime is incredibly soft yet tough. It lodges in the shark’s delicate gills, and as the shark chokes 
and tries to clear the slime, it releases the hagfish. Now, the hagfish is free 
from the jaws of death. But it’s in a dilemma of its own doing, trapped in a cloud of its own
suffocating slime. So what does it do? Well, it ties itself in a knot, of course. Starting at its tail 
and passing its body through, the hagfish effectively wipes away
its own slime. Apparently unfazed by the whole encounter, it returns to its meal. When it gets to a tougher part 
of the carcass... Voila! The hagfish ties itself 
in yet another knot to gain leverage and yank off the meat. The hagfish’s slime is so remarkable
that people are trying to emulate it. Currently, a lot of athletic 
and safety gear is made from non-renewable
petroleum-based fibers. But hagfish slime threads rival 
the properties of materials like nylon. And fibers modeled after those 
in hagfish slime may present a much more sustainable alternative. Meanwhile, hagfish slime is also being 
explored in military contexts as a non-lethal weapon that could be used
to stop boats by sliming up their propellers. In addition to mastering
the art of slime and knot-tying, hagfish have four little hearts and can survive 36 hours 
without oxygen unscathed. Oh, and they also clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients 
in the deep sea. Proto-hagfish were navigating
the ocean’s depths more than 300 million years ago— before dinosaurs roamed 
and back when Pangea was still a thing. Having persisted through multiple
mass extinction events, hagfish have just about seen it all. And it would appear that they’re still
having a wonderful slime.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many times its original volume can hagfish slime expand?
Options: A. 10, B. 100, C. 1,000, D. 10,000
Correct Option: D

Question 5: Why are researchers interested in emulating hagfish slime? Options: A. Because it is incredibly soft and fragile., B. Because it is incredibly soft yet tough and could be used to create sustainable materials., C. Because it is only found in hagfish., D. Because it is not useful for any practical applications. Correct Option: B

They clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients in the deep sea., C. They are prey for many other sea creatures and help to support the food chain., D. Question 10: How long have hagfish been present on Earth? Options: A. For over 100 million years., B. For over 300 million years., C. For over 500 million years., D. For over 1 billion years. Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
As the truck screeched to a halt,
one of its containers slid off, hit an approaching Prius 
and spilled its contents. Those contents happened to be thousands
of kilograms of live hagfish, also known as slime eels. The result of this 2017 car accident 
was an absolute mess: the highway was littered 
with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime that took 
the fire department 7 hours to clear. Astonishingly good looks aside, the standout strength of all hagfishes
is their slime. In fact, they’re probably 
Earth’s slimiest animals. But why be so slimy? Watch and learn. This hagfish has detected a dead fish
using its keen sense of smell and the tastebud-like organs 
dotting its skin. Revealing imposing rows of toothlike
structures, it takes the first bite. A shark glides on to the scene
and suddenly lunges. Being caught in the shark’s powerful jaws
may seem like a guaranteed death sentence, but the hagfish has some tricks 
up its sleeve. The shark’s teeth clench down
but there are no bones to crush— only flexible cartilage. And because the hagfish’s skin is so 
loosely attached to the rest of its body, the pressure from the bite causes the hagfish’s essential organs
to slip out of the way, avoiding damage. This is where being a noodle 
in a baggy wetsuit really pays off. Meanwhile, the hagfish also actively
repels the shark by spewing a stupendous supply of slime. Around a hundred slime glands
line each side of the hagfish’s body. Within them are mucus and thread cells. The mucus cells are packed with hundreds
of vesicles of condensed mucus while each thread cell contains 
an intricately coiled protein fiber. The hagfish contracts the muscles
surrounding some of its slime glands, causing the cells to eject their contents
into the seawater. In a fraction of a second, 
the mucus vesicles swell and burst, and the protein fibers unravel. Together, they expand to 10,000 times
their original volume, instantly creating liters of slime. Because the substance is composed of mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine 
and strong silk-like fibers, the slime is incredibly soft yet tough. It lodges in the shark’s delicate gills, and as the shark chokes 
and tries to clear the slime, it releases the hagfish. Now, the hagfish is free 
from the jaws of death. But it’s in a dilemma of its own doing, trapped in a cloud of its own
suffocating slime. So what does it do? Well, it ties itself in a knot, of course. Starting at its tail 
and passing its body through, the hagfish effectively wipes away
its own slime. Apparently unfazed by the whole encounter, it returns to its meal. When it gets to a tougher part 
of the carcass... Voila! The hagfish ties itself 
in yet another knot to gain leverage and yank off the meat. The hagfish’s slime is so remarkable
that people are trying to emulate it. Currently, a lot of athletic 
and safety gear is made from non-renewable
petroleum-based fibers. But hagfish slime threads rival 
the properties of materials like nylon. And fibers modeled after those 
in hagfish slime may present a much more sustainable alternative. Meanwhile, hagfish slime is also being 
explored in military contexts as a non-lethal weapon that could be used
to stop boats by sliming up their propellers. In addition to mastering
the art of slime and knot-tying, hagfish have four little hearts and can survive 36 hours 
without oxygen unscathed. Oh, and they also clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients 
in the deep sea. Proto-hagfish were navigating
the ocean’s depths more than 300 million years ago— before dinosaurs roamed 
and back when Pangea was still a thing. Having persisted through multiple
mass extinction events, hagfish have just about seen it all. And it would appear that they’re still
having a wonderful slime.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these is NOT a reason why people are trying to mimic hagfish slime?
Options: A. It is more sustainable than petroleum-based alternatives, B. It can rival the strength of many artificial fibers, C. It is harder than concrete, D. It may be effective at stopping boat propellers
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the result of the 2017 car accident involving a truck carrying live hagfish? Options: A. The highway was littered with dead fish and debris., B. The highway was littered with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime., C. The truck driver was injured and taken to the hospital., D. The accident caused a massive traffic jam. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the standout strength of all hagfishes? Options: A. Their ability to detect dead fish using their keen sense of smell., B. Their imposing rows of toothlike structures., C. Their slime., D. Their ability to survive without oxygen for 36 hours. Correct Option: C
Question 3: How do hagfish protect themselves from predators like sharks? Options: A. By using their toothlike structures to defend themselves., B. Question 5: Why are researchers interested in emulating hagfish slime? Options: A. Because it is incredibly soft and fragile., B. Because it is incredibly soft yet tough and could be used to create sustainable materials., C. Because it is only found in hagfish., D. Because it is not useful for any practical applications. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one potential military application of hagfish slime? Options: A. As a lethal weapon to kill enemy soldiers., B. As a non-lethal weapon to stop boats by sliming up their propellers., C. As a tool for espionage., D. As a way to protect against chemical attacks. Correct Option: B

**Question 5: Why are researchers interested in emulating hagfish slime?**

Correct Option: B

This generated MCQ matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, which is to understand the reasons behind researchers' interest in mimicking hagfish slime. The options in both MCQs also overlap, with the correct option in the generated MCQ (B) mentioning the sustainability aspect, which is also present in the ground truth MCQ (A).

However, it's worth noting that the generated MCQ does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, as it does not provide an option that is explicitly incorrect (like option C in the ground truth MCQ). Nevertheless, Question 5 is the most similar generated MCQ in terms of content and intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As the truck screeched to a halt,
one of its containers slid off, hit an approaching Prius 
and spilled its contents. Those contents happened to be thousands
of kilograms of live hagfish, also known as slime eels. The result of this 2017 car accident 
was an absolute mess: the highway was littered 
with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime that took 
the fire department 7 hours to clear. Astonishingly good looks aside, the standout strength of all hagfishes
is their slime. In fact, they’re probably 
Earth’s slimiest animals. But why be so slimy? Watch and learn. This hagfish has detected a dead fish
using its keen sense of smell and the tastebud-like organs 
dotting its skin. Revealing imposing rows of toothlike
structures, it takes the first bite. A shark glides on to the scene
and suddenly lunges. Being caught in the shark’s powerful jaws
may seem like a guaranteed death sentence, but the hagfish has some tricks 
up its sleeve. The shark’s teeth clench down
but there are no bones to crush— only flexible cartilage. And because the hagfish’s skin is so 
loosely attached to the rest of its body, the pressure from the bite causes the hagfish’s essential organs
to slip out of the way, avoiding damage. This is where being a noodle 
in a baggy wetsuit really pays off. Meanwhile, the hagfish also actively
repels the shark by spewing a stupendous supply of slime. Around a hundred slime glands
line each side of the hagfish’s body. Within them are mucus and thread cells. The mucus cells are packed with hundreds
of vesicles of condensed mucus while each thread cell contains 
an intricately coiled protein fiber. The hagfish contracts the muscles
surrounding some of its slime glands, causing the cells to eject their contents
into the seawater. In a fraction of a second, 
the mucus vesicles swell and burst, and the protein fibers unravel. Together, they expand to 10,000 times
their original volume, instantly creating liters of slime. Because the substance is composed of mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine 
and strong silk-like fibers, the slime is incredibly soft yet tough. It lodges in the shark’s delicate gills, and as the shark chokes 
and tries to clear the slime, it releases the hagfish. Now, the hagfish is free 
from the jaws of death. But it’s in a dilemma of its own doing, trapped in a cloud of its own
suffocating slime. So what does it do? Well, it ties itself in a knot, of course. Starting at its tail 
and passing its body through, the hagfish effectively wipes away
its own slime. Apparently unfazed by the whole encounter, it returns to its meal. When it gets to a tougher part 
of the carcass... Voila! The hagfish ties itself 
in yet another knot to gain leverage and yank off the meat. The hagfish’s slime is so remarkable
that people are trying to emulate it. Currently, a lot of athletic 
and safety gear is made from non-renewable
petroleum-based fibers. But hagfish slime threads rival 
the properties of materials like nylon. And fibers modeled after those 
in hagfish slime may present a much more sustainable alternative. Meanwhile, hagfish slime is also being 
explored in military contexts as a non-lethal weapon that could be used
to stop boats by sliming up their propellers. In addition to mastering
the art of slime and knot-tying, hagfish have four little hearts and can survive 36 hours 
without oxygen unscathed. Oh, and they also clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients 
in the deep sea. Proto-hagfish were navigating
the ocean’s depths more than 300 million years ago— before dinosaurs roamed 
and back when Pangea was still a thing. Having persisted through multiple
mass extinction events, hagfish have just about seen it all. And it would appear that they’re still
having a wonderful slime.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do hagfish remove excess slime from their skin?
Options: A. By tying themselves into knots, B. The excess slime quickly dissolves away, C. By eating the slime, D. By wiggling aggressively
Correct Option: A

They clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients in the deep sea., C. They are prey for many other sea creatures and help to support the food chain., D. They have no significant role in the ecosystem. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How long have hagfish been present on Earth? Options: A. For over 100 million years., B. For over 300 million years., C. For over 500 million years., D. For over 1 billion years. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: How do hagfish clean themselves after releasing slime? 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine how hagfish remove excess slime from their skin. The correct option for both questions is also the same, which involves the hagfish tying itself in a knot to wipe away the slime.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What’s the best country 
in the world to live in? Is it the one with the best food?
The longest life expectancy? The best weather? For the past 70 years, most governments 
have relied heavily on a single number to answer that question. This number influences elections, 
the stock market, and government policy. But it was never intended
for its current purpose; and some would argue that the world 
is addicted to making it grow... forever. This number is called 
the Gross Domestic Product, or GDP, and it was invented by the economist
Simon Kuznets in the 1930s, to try and gauge the size of an economy
in a single, easy to understand number. GDP is the total monetary value 
of everything a country produces and sells on the market. To this day, GDP per capita, which is just the total GDP divided by the
number of people living in that country, is widely seen as a measure of well-being. But GDP doesn’t actually say anything
direct about well-being, because it doesn't take into account
what a country produces or who has access to it. A million dollars of weapons contributes 
the exact same amount to a country’s GDP as a million dollars of vaccines or food. The value society derives from things
like public school or firefighters isn’t counted in GDP at all, because those
services aren’t sold on the market. And if a country has a lot of wealth, but most of it is controlled
by relatively few people, GDP per capita gives a distorted picture
of how much money a typical person has. Despite all that, for a long time, higher GDP did correlate closely
to a higher quality of life for people in many countries. From 1945 to 1970, as GDP doubled,
tripled or even quadrupled in some western economies, people’s wages often grew proportionally. By the 1980s, this changed. Countries continued to grow richer, but wages stopped keeping pace 
with GDP growth, or in some cases, even declined, and most of the benefits went to an 
ever-smaller percentage of the population. Still, the idea of capturing
a nation’s well-being in a single number had powerful appeal. In 1972, King Jigme Singye Wangchuk
of Bhutan came up with the idea 
of Gross National Happiness as an alternative 
to Gross Domestic Product. Gross National Happiness is a metric 
that factors in matters like health, education, 
strong communities, and living standards, having citizens answer questions like, “How happy do you think your family
members are at the moment?” “What is your knowledge of names of plants
and wild animals in your area?” and “What type of day was yesterday?” The United Nations’ Human Development
Index is a more widely used metric; it takes into account health
and education, as well as income per capita 
to estimate overall well-being. Meanwhile, a metric called
the Sustainable Development Index factors in both well-being and the 
environmental burdens of economic growth, again, boiling all this down
to a single number. Though no country has been able to meet the basic needs of its people while also using resources 
fully sustainably, Costa Rica currently comes the closest. Over the past few decades, it’s managed to grow its economy
and improve living standards substantially without drastically increasing 
its emissions. Other countries,
like Colombia and Jordan, have made notable progress. Costa Rica now has better well-being
outcomes like life expectancy than some of the world’s 
richest countries. Ultimately, there are limits 
to any approach that boils the quality of life in a country 
down to a single number. Increasingly, experts favor a dashboard
approach that lays out all the factors a single number obscures. This approach makes even more sense given 
that people have different priorities, and the answer to which country 
is best to live in depends on who’s asking the question. So what if that were you designing 
your countries well-being metric? What do you value, 
and what would you measure?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is GDP?
Options: A. Total value of everything that is bought in a country, B. The total value of everything sold in a country, C. Total monetary value of everything a country produces and sells on the market, D. The total value of an entire country's infrastructure
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who invented the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the 1930s? Options: A. King Jigme Singye Wangchuk, B. Simon Kuznets, C. John Maynard Keynes, D. Milton Friedman Correct Option: B
Question 2: What does GDP per capita represent? Options: A. Total GDP divided by the number of businesses in a country, B. Total GDP divided by the number of people living in a country, C. Total GDP multiplied by the number of people living in a country, D. Total GDP minus the number of people living in a country Correct Option: B
Question 3: A country has a high GDP due to its large military spending. What can be inferred about the country's well-being? Options: A. The country's well-being is directly proportional to its GDP, B. The country's well-being is not necessarily reflected by its GDP, C. The country's well-being is inversely proportional to its GDP, D. The country's well-being is irrelevant to its GDP Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the main limitation of using GDP as a measure of well-being? Options: A. It only accounts for monetary transactions, B. It only accounts for non-monetary transactions, C. It only accounts for government spending, D. It only accounts for international trade Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the United Nations' Human Development Index (HDI) used to estimate? Options: A. Economic growth, B. Environmental sustainability, C. Overall well-being, D. Military strength Correct Option: C
Question 6: Which country is currently closest to meeting the basic needs of its people while using resources sustainably? Options: A. Costa Rica, B. Colombia, C. Jordan, D. United States Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the main advantage of using a dashboard approach to measure well-being? Options: A. It provides a single, easy-to-understand number, B. It obscures various factors that affect well-being, C. It allows for a more comprehensive understanding of well-being, D. It is easier to calculate than a single metric Correct Option: C
Question 8: If you were designing a well-being metric for a country, what factors would you consider? (Select the most appropriate answer) Options: A. Only economic growth and income per capita, B. Only health and education outcomes, C. A combination of economic, social, and environmental factors, D. Only military strength and international influence Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main difference between the Sustainable Development Index and the Human Development Index? Options: A. The Sustainable Development Index only accounts for economic growth, while the Human Development Index only accounts for health and education, B. The Sustainable Development Index accounts for environmental burdens, while the Human Development Index does not, C. The Sustainable Development Index only accounts for social factors, while the Human Development Index only accounts for economic factors, D. The Sustainable Development Index is used for developed countries, while the Human Development Index is used for developing countries Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why do experts increasingly favor a dashboard approach to measuring well-being? Options: A. Because it provides a single, easy-to-understand number, B. Because it allows for a more comprehensive understanding of well-being, C. Because it is easier to calculate than a single metric, D. Because it is less accurate than a single metric Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: What is the main limitation of using GDP as a measure of well-being? 

However, the options provided in Question 4 do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. A more accurate match in terms of question content would be a generated MCQ that directly asks for the definition of GDP.

Among the provided generated MCQs, Question 2 is the closest match in terms of content, but it asks about GDP per capita instead of GDP.

Since none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ, I will choose the one that is closest in terms of content. However, I must note that the options provided in the generated MCQs do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4 (with the caveat that it does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ)

Question: What is GDP?
Options: A. Total value of everything that is bought in a country, B. The total value of everything sold in a country, C. Total monetary value of everything a country produces and sells on the market, D. The total value of an entire country's infrastructure

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What’s the best country 
in the world to live in? Is it the one with the best food?
The longest life expectancy? The best weather? For the past 70 years, most governments 
have relied heavily on a single number to answer that question. This number influences elections, 
the stock market, and government policy. But it was never intended
for its current purpose; and some would argue that the world 
is addicted to making it grow... forever. This number is called 
the Gross Domestic Product, or GDP, and it was invented by the economist
Simon Kuznets in the 1930s, to try and gauge the size of an economy
in a single, easy to understand number. GDP is the total monetary value 
of everything a country produces and sells on the market. To this day, GDP per capita, which is just the total GDP divided by the
number of people living in that country, is widely seen as a measure of well-being. But GDP doesn’t actually say anything
direct about well-being, because it doesn't take into account
what a country produces or who has access to it. A million dollars of weapons contributes 
the exact same amount to a country’s GDP as a million dollars of vaccines or food. The value society derives from things
like public school or firefighters isn’t counted in GDP at all, because those
services aren’t sold on the market. And if a country has a lot of wealth, but most of it is controlled
by relatively few people, GDP per capita gives a distorted picture
of how much money a typical person has. Despite all that, for a long time, higher GDP did correlate closely
to a higher quality of life for people in many countries. From 1945 to 1970, as GDP doubled,
tripled or even quadrupled in some western economies, people’s wages often grew proportionally. By the 1980s, this changed. Countries continued to grow richer, but wages stopped keeping pace 
with GDP growth, or in some cases, even declined, and most of the benefits went to an 
ever-smaller percentage of the population. Still, the idea of capturing
a nation’s well-being in a single number had powerful appeal. In 1972, King Jigme Singye Wangchuk
of Bhutan came up with the idea 
of Gross National Happiness as an alternative 
to Gross Domestic Product. Gross National Happiness is a metric 
that factors in matters like health, education, 
strong communities, and living standards, having citizens answer questions like, “How happy do you think your family
members are at the moment?” “What is your knowledge of names of plants
and wild animals in your area?” and “What type of day was yesterday?” The United Nations’ Human Development
Index is a more widely used metric; it takes into account health
and education, as well as income per capita 
to estimate overall well-being. Meanwhile, a metric called
the Sustainable Development Index factors in both well-being and the 
environmental burdens of economic growth, again, boiling all this down
to a single number. Though no country has been able to meet the basic needs of its people while also using resources 
fully sustainably, Costa Rica currently comes the closest. Over the past few decades, it’s managed to grow its economy
and improve living standards substantially without drastically increasing 
its emissions. Other countries,
like Colombia and Jordan, have made notable progress. Costa Rica now has better well-being
outcomes like life expectancy than some of the world’s 
richest countries. Ultimately, there are limits 
to any approach that boils the quality of life in a country 
down to a single number. Increasingly, experts favor a dashboard
approach that lays out all the factors a single number obscures. This approach makes even more sense given 
that people have different priorities, and the answer to which country 
is best to live in depends on who’s asking the question. So what if that were you designing 
your countries well-being metric? What do you value, 
and what would you measure?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are somethings GDP does NOT capture
Options: A. Services that are provided but not sold on the market place (like public schools and fire fighting), B. Levels of inequality (the amount of people who have wealth vs. who does not), C. How happy people are with their lives, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

of everything a country produces and sells on the market. To this day, GDP per capita, which is just the total GDP divided by the
number of people living in that country, is widely seen as a measure of well-being. But GDP doesn’t actually say anything
direct about well-being, because it doesn't take into account
what a country produces or who has access to it. A million dollars of weapons contributes 
the exact same amount to a country’s GDP as a million dollars of vaccines or food. The value society derives from things
like public school or firefighters isn’t counted in GDP at all, because those

your countries well-being metric? What do you value, 
and what would you measure?

Question: _____ is an alternative to GDP that captures health, education, strong communities and living standards
Options: A. Gross National Happiness (GNH), B. Gross Domestic Wellbeing (GNW), C. Wholistic Value-Added (WVA), D. Community Aggregate Valuation (CAV)
Correct Option: A

Question 4: What is the main limitation of using GDP as a measure of well-being? Options: A. It only accounts for monetary transactions, B. It only accounts for non-monetary transactions, C. It only accounts for government spending, D. It only accounts for international trade Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the United Nations' Human Development Index (HDI) used to estimate? Options: A. Economic growth, B. Environmental sustainability, C. Overall well-being, D. Military strength Correct Option: C
Question 6: Which country is currently closest to meeting the basic needs of its people while using resources sustainably? Options: A. Costa Rica, B. Colombia, C. Jordan, D. United States Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the main advantage of using a dashboard approach to measure well-being? Options: A. It provides a single, easy-to-understand number, B. It obscures various factors that affect well-being, C. It allows for a more comprehensive understanding of well-being, D. It is easier to calculate than a single metric Correct Option: C
Question 8: If you were designing a well-being metric for a country, what factors would you consider? (Select the most appropriate answer) Options: A. Only economic growth and income per capita, B. Only health and education outcomes, C. A combination of economic, social, and environmental factors, D. Only military strength and international influence Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main difference between the Sustainable Development Index and the Human Development Index? Options: A. The Sustainable Development Index only accounts for economic growth, while the Human Development Index only accounts for health and education, B. The Sustainable Development Index accounts for environmental burdens, while the Human Development Index does not, C. The Sustainable Development Index only accounts for social factors, while the Human Development Index only accounts for economic factors, D. The Sustainable Development Index is used for developed countries, while the Human Development Index is used for developing countries Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why do experts increasingly favor a dashboard approach to measuring well-being? Options: A. Because it provides a single, easy-to-understand number, B. Because it allows for a more comprehensive understanding of well-being, C. Because it is easier to calculate than a single metric, D. Because it is less accurate than a single metric Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If someone teleported from sea level
to the top of Mt. Everest, things would go bad fast. At an altitude of 8,848 meters, barometric pressure is approximately
33% of what it is at sea level. This means there's significantly
less oxygen in the air, and our teleported individual would
likely suffocate in minutes. However, for people that make this same
journey over the course of a month, it's possible to survive
at the peak for hours. So what can happen to our bodies 
in just one month that allows us to endure
this incredible altitude? Let’s imagine you’re one 
of the 5.8 billion people living less than 500 meters 
above sea level. When you take a breath at this altitude, your lungs fill up with air composed
of numerous gases and compounds. Most important among these 
are oxygen molecules, which bind to the hemoglobin 
in your red blood cells. Blood then circulates 
throughout your body, bringing essential oxygen
to all your cells. But as altitude increases, 
the air starts to get thinner. The relative amounts of each compound
remain the same well into the upper atmosphere, but overall, there is less oxygen 
for our bodies to absorb. And if you ascend to altitudes
above 2,500 meters, the resulting oxygen deprivation can cause
a form of altitude sickness known as AMS, often causing headaches,
fatigue and nausea. Fortunately, AMS only happens
when we ascend too fast, because our bodies have numerous ways
of adapting to high altitudes. Within minutes or even seconds 
of reaching altitudes of 1,500 meters, carotid chemoreceptors in your neck
sense your blood’s low oxygen pressure. This triggers a response that increases 
the rate and depth of your breathing to counteract the lack of oxygen. Your heart rate also increases and your heart contracts more tightly 
to pump additional blood with each beat, quickly moving oxygenated
blood around your body. All these changes happen relatively fast,
and if you were to keep ascending, your heart rate and breathing
would speed up accordingly. But if you stayed at this altitude
for several weeks, you could reap the benefits 
of some longer-term adaptations. Within the first few days 
above 1,500 meters, the volume of plasma 
in your blood decreases, which increases the concentration
of hemoglobin. Over the next two weeks, your hemoglobin
levels will continue to rise, allowing your blood to carry 
even more oxygen per milliliter. Paired with your high heart rate, this new hemoglobin-rich blood efficiently
distributes oxygen throughout your body. So much so that the volume of blood 
being pumped with each heartbeat can return to normal levels. Over this same time, your breathing 
also increases even further in a process called 
ventilatory acclimatization. After this several weeks 
of extended acclimatization, your body has made enough significant
changes to climb even higher. However, you’ll still have to spend
additional time acclimating along the way, often climbing back down to recover 
before ascending even higher. Because the summit of Everest
isn't just high, it’s the highest place on Earth. And at altitudes above 3,500 meters, 
our bodies are under incredible stress. Arteries and veins in the brain
dilate to speed up blood flow, But our smallest blood vessels,
called capillaries, remain the same size. This increased pressure can cause
blood vessels to leak, and fluid to build up in the brain. A similar issue can occur in the lungs, where low oxygen causes blood vessels 
to constrict, leading to more leaking vessels
and fluid buildup. These two conditions— 
known as HACE and HAPE, respectively— are incredibly rare, but can be life-threatening 
if not dealt with quickly. Some Tibetans and South Americans 
with family histories of living at high altitude have genetic advantages that can 
prevent minor altitude sickness, but even they aren’t immune
to these severe conditions. Yet despite these risks, 
climbers over the last century have proved people can go higher 
than scientists ever thought possible. Pushing past their body’s limitations, these climbers have redefined
what humanity can adapt to.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: At the summit of Mount Everest, the barometric pressure is ____% of what it is at sea level?
Options: A. 11, B. 22, C. 33, D. 44
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate barometric pressure at the top of Mt. Everest compared to sea level? Options: A. 50%, B. 33%, C. 25%, D. 10% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What happens to the oxygen levels in the air as altitude increases? Options: A. The relative amounts of oxygen increase, B. The relative amounts of oxygen remain the same, but overall oxygen levels decrease, C. The relative amounts of oxygen decrease, D. The relative amounts of oxygen remain the same, and overall oxygen levels increase Correct Option: B
Question 3: A person is planning to climb a mountain with an altitude of 3,000 meters. What advice would you give them to avoid altitude sickness? Options: A. Ascend to the summit as quickly as possible, B. Ascend gradually, taking several weeks to acclimate to the high altitude, C. Stay at sea level for a month before ascending, D. Take medication to prevent altitude sickness Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary function of carotid chemoreceptors in the neck when sensing low oxygen pressure at high altitudes? Options: A. To decrease heart rate and breathing rate, B. To increase heart rate and breathing rate, C. To maintain normal heart rate and breathing rate, D. To decrease blood pressure Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the result of the decrease in plasma volume in the blood after several days at high altitude? Options: A. Decreased concentration of hemoglobin, B. Increased concentration of hemoglobin, C. No change in hemoglobin concentration, D. Decreased heart rate Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the condition that occurs when fluid builds up in the brain due to increased pressure at high altitudes? Options: A. HAPE, B. HACE, C. AMS, D. Hypoxia Correct Option: B
Question 7: Analyze the relationship between altitude and oxygen levels in the air. How do these factors impact the human body? Options: A. As altitude increases, oxygen levels decrease, leading to increased heart rate and breathing rate, B. As altitude increases, oxygen levels increase, leading to decreased heart rate and breathing rate, C. As altitude increases, oxygen levels remain the same, leading to no changes in heart rate and breathing rate, D. As altitude decreases, oxygen levels decrease, leading to increased heart rate and breathing rate Correct Option: A
Question 8: What can be inferred about the genetic advantages of Tibetans and South Americans who have lived at high altitudes for generations? Options: A. They are immune to all forms of altitude sickness, B. They are more susceptible to severe altitude sickness, C. They have a lower risk of minor altitude sickness, but are not immune to severe conditions, D. They have no genetic advantages related to high altitude adaptation Correct Option: C
Question 9: Evaluate the risks and benefits of climbing to extreme altitudes. What can be concluded about human adaptation to high altitudes? Options: A. Humans are not capable of adapting to high altitudes and should avoid climbing to extreme elevations, B. Humans can adapt to high altitudes, but only with extensive training and acclimatization, C. Humans can adapt to high altitudes, and with proper acclimatization, can climb to extreme elevations with minimal risk, D. Humans are naturally adapted to high altitudes and do not require acclimatization Correct Option: C
Question 10: Synthesize the information about high altitude adaptation and propose a plan for a climber to ascend to the summit of Mt. Everest safely. Options: A. Ascend to the summit in one day, taking regular breaks to rest and acclimate, B. Ascend to the summit over the course of several weeks, taking time to acclimate to each new altitude, C. Ascend to the summit in a few days, using medication to prevent altitude sickness, D. Ascend to the summit alone, without any prior experience or acclimatization Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (comparing barometric pressure at the top of Mt. Everest to sea level), options (providing percentage values), and content (focusing on the specific percentage value of barometric pressure at the summit of Mt. Everest).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If someone teleported from sea level
to the top of Mt. Everest, things would go bad fast. At an altitude of 8,848 meters, barometric pressure is approximately
33% of what it is at sea level. This means there's significantly
less oxygen in the air, and our teleported individual would
likely suffocate in minutes. However, for people that make this same
journey over the course of a month, it's possible to survive
at the peak for hours. So what can happen to our bodies 
in just one month that allows us to endure
this incredible altitude? Let’s imagine you’re one 
of the 5.8 billion people living less than 500 meters 
above sea level. When you take a breath at this altitude, your lungs fill up with air composed
of numerous gases and compounds. Most important among these 
are oxygen molecules, which bind to the hemoglobin 
in your red blood cells. Blood then circulates 
throughout your body, bringing essential oxygen
to all your cells. But as altitude increases, 
the air starts to get thinner. The relative amounts of each compound
remain the same well into the upper atmosphere, but overall, there is less oxygen 
for our bodies to absorb. And if you ascend to altitudes
above 2,500 meters, the resulting oxygen deprivation can cause
a form of altitude sickness known as AMS, often causing headaches,
fatigue and nausea. Fortunately, AMS only happens
when we ascend too fast, because our bodies have numerous ways
of adapting to high altitudes. Within minutes or even seconds 
of reaching altitudes of 1,500 meters, carotid chemoreceptors in your neck
sense your blood’s low oxygen pressure. This triggers a response that increases 
the rate and depth of your breathing to counteract the lack of oxygen. Your heart rate also increases and your heart contracts more tightly 
to pump additional blood with each beat, quickly moving oxygenated
blood around your body. All these changes happen relatively fast,
and if you were to keep ascending, your heart rate and breathing
would speed up accordingly. But if you stayed at this altitude
for several weeks, you could reap the benefits 
of some longer-term adaptations. Within the first few days 
above 1,500 meters, the volume of plasma 
in your blood decreases, which increases the concentration
of hemoglobin. Over the next two weeks, your hemoglobin
levels will continue to rise, allowing your blood to carry 
even more oxygen per milliliter. Paired with your high heart rate, this new hemoglobin-rich blood efficiently
distributes oxygen throughout your body. So much so that the volume of blood 
being pumped with each heartbeat can return to normal levels. Over this same time, your breathing 
also increases even further in a process called 
ventilatory acclimatization. After this several weeks 
of extended acclimatization, your body has made enough significant
changes to climb even higher. However, you’ll still have to spend
additional time acclimating along the way, often climbing back down to recover 
before ascending even higher. Because the summit of Everest
isn't just high, it’s the highest place on Earth. And at altitudes above 3,500 meters, 
our bodies are under incredible stress. Arteries and veins in the brain
dilate to speed up blood flow, But our smallest blood vessels,
called capillaries, remain the same size. This increased pressure can cause
blood vessels to leak, and fluid to build up in the brain. A similar issue can occur in the lungs, where low oxygen causes blood vessels 
to constrict, leading to more leaking vessels
and fluid buildup. These two conditions— 
known as HACE and HAPE, respectively— are incredibly rare, but can be life-threatening 
if not dealt with quickly. Some Tibetans and South Americans 
with family histories of living at high altitude have genetic advantages that can 
prevent minor altitude sickness, but even they aren’t immune
to these severe conditions. Yet despite these risks, 
climbers over the last century have proved people can go higher 
than scientists ever thought possible. Pushing past their body’s limitations, these climbers have redefined
what humanity can adapt to.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Acute mountain sickness can cause which following symptoms:
Options: A. Headache, B. Nausea, C. Fatigue, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

The relative amounts of oxygen remain the same, but overall oxygen levels decrease, C. The relative amounts of oxygen decrease, D. The relative amounts of oxygen remain the same, and overall oxygen levels increase Correct Option: B

To increase heart rate and breathing rate, C. To maintain normal heart rate and breathing rate, D. To decrease blood pressure Correct Option: B

As altitude increases, oxygen levels decrease, leading to increased heart rate and breathing rate, B. As altitude increases, oxygen levels increase, leading to decreased heart rate and breathing rate, C. As altitude increases, oxygen levels remain the same, leading to no changes in heart rate and breathing rate, D. As altitude decreases, oxygen levels decrease, leading to increased heart rate and breathing rate Correct Option: A
Question 8: What can be inferred about the genetic advantages of Tibetans and South Americans who have lived at high altitudes for generations? Options: A. They are immune to all forms of altitude sickness, B. They are more susceptible to severe altitude sickness, C. They have a lower risk of minor altitude sickness, but are not immune to severe conditions, D. They have no genetic advantages related to high altitude adaptation Correct Option: C

Humans can adapt to high altitudes, and with proper acclimatization, can climb to extreme elevations with minimal risk, D. Humans are naturally adapted to high altitudes and do not require acclimatization Correct Option: C

Ascend to the summit in one day, taking regular breaks to rest and acclimate, B. Ascend to the summit over the course of several weeks, taking time to acclimate to each new altitude, C. Ascend to the summit in a few days, using medication to prevent altitude sickness, D. Ascend to the summit alone, without any prior experience or acclimatization Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If someone teleported from sea level
to the top of Mt. Everest, things would go bad fast. At an altitude of 8,848 meters, barometric pressure is approximately
33% of what it is at sea level. This means there's significantly
less oxygen in the air, and our teleported individual would
likely suffocate in minutes. However, for people that make this same
journey over the course of a month, it's possible to survive
at the peak for hours. So what can happen to our bodies 
in just one month that allows us to endure
this incredible altitude? Let’s imagine you’re one 
of the 5.8 billion people living less than 500 meters 
above sea level. When you take a breath at this altitude, your lungs fill up with air composed
of numerous gases and compounds. Most important among these 
are oxygen molecules, which bind to the hemoglobin 
in your red blood cells. Blood then circulates 
throughout your body, bringing essential oxygen
to all your cells. But as altitude increases, 
the air starts to get thinner. The relative amounts of each compound
remain the same well into the upper atmosphere, but overall, there is less oxygen 
for our bodies to absorb. And if you ascend to altitudes
above 2,500 meters, the resulting oxygen deprivation can cause
a form of altitude sickness known as AMS, often causing headaches,
fatigue and nausea. Fortunately, AMS only happens
when we ascend too fast, because our bodies have numerous ways
of adapting to high altitudes. Within minutes or even seconds 
of reaching altitudes of 1,500 meters, carotid chemoreceptors in your neck
sense your blood’s low oxygen pressure. This triggers a response that increases 
the rate and depth of your breathing to counteract the lack of oxygen. Your heart rate also increases and your heart contracts more tightly 
to pump additional blood with each beat, quickly moving oxygenated
blood around your body. All these changes happen relatively fast,
and if you were to keep ascending, your heart rate and breathing
would speed up accordingly. But if you stayed at this altitude
for several weeks, you could reap the benefits 
of some longer-term adaptations. Within the first few days 
above 1,500 meters, the volume of plasma 
in your blood decreases, which increases the concentration
of hemoglobin. Over the next two weeks, your hemoglobin
levels will continue to rise, allowing your blood to carry 
even more oxygen per milliliter. Paired with your high heart rate, this new hemoglobin-rich blood efficiently
distributes oxygen throughout your body. So much so that the volume of blood 
being pumped with each heartbeat can return to normal levels. Over this same time, your breathing 
also increases even further in a process called 
ventilatory acclimatization. After this several weeks 
of extended acclimatization, your body has made enough significant
changes to climb even higher. However, you’ll still have to spend
additional time acclimating along the way, often climbing back down to recover 
before ascending even higher. Because the summit of Everest
isn't just high, it’s the highest place on Earth. And at altitudes above 3,500 meters, 
our bodies are under incredible stress. Arteries and veins in the brain
dilate to speed up blood flow, But our smallest blood vessels,
called capillaries, remain the same size. This increased pressure can cause
blood vessels to leak, and fluid to build up in the brain. A similar issue can occur in the lungs, where low oxygen causes blood vessels 
to constrict, leading to more leaking vessels
and fluid buildup. These two conditions— 
known as HACE and HAPE, respectively— are incredibly rare, but can be life-threatening 
if not dealt with quickly. Some Tibetans and South Americans 
with family histories of living at high altitude have genetic advantages that can 
prevent minor altitude sickness, but even they aren’t immune
to these severe conditions. Yet despite these risks, 
climbers over the last century have proved people can go higher 
than scientists ever thought possible. Pushing past their body’s limitations, these climbers have redefined
what humanity can adapt to.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Low blood oxygen is sensed by the carotid body which results in:
Options: A. An increase in breathing rate and depth, B. A decrease in breathing rate and depth, C. An increase in red blood cells, D. A decrease in red blood cells
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If someone teleported from sea level
to the top of Mt. Everest, things would go bad fast. At an altitude of 8,848 meters, barometric pressure is approximately
33% of what it is at sea level. This means there's significantly
less oxygen in the air, and our teleported individual would
likely suffocate in minutes. However, for people that make this same
journey over the course of a month, it's possible to survive
at the peak for hours. So what can happen to our bodies 
in just one month that allows us to endure
this incredible altitude? Let’s imagine you’re one 
of the 5.8 billion people living less than 500 meters 
above sea level. When you take a breath at this altitude, your lungs fill up with air composed
of numerous gases and compounds. Most important among these 
are oxygen molecules, which bind to the hemoglobin 
in your red blood cells. Blood then circulates 
throughout your body, bringing essential oxygen
to all your cells. But as altitude increases, 
the air starts to get thinner. The relative amounts of each compound
remain the same well into the upper atmosphere, but overall, there is less oxygen 
for our bodies to absorb. And if you ascend to altitudes
above 2,500 meters, the resulting oxygen deprivation can cause
a form of altitude sickness known as AMS, often causing headaches,
fatigue and nausea. Fortunately, AMS only happens
when we ascend too fast, because our bodies have numerous ways
of adapting to high altitudes. Within minutes or even seconds 
of reaching altitudes of 1,500 meters, carotid chemoreceptors in your neck
sense your blood’s low oxygen pressure. This triggers a response that increases 
the rate and depth of your breathing to counteract the lack of oxygen. Your heart rate also increases and your heart contracts more tightly 
to pump additional blood with each beat, quickly moving oxygenated
blood around your body. All these changes happen relatively fast,
and if you were to keep ascending, your heart rate and breathing
would speed up accordingly. But if you stayed at this altitude
for several weeks, you could reap the benefits 
of some longer-term adaptations. Within the first few days 
above 1,500 meters, the volume of plasma 
in your blood decreases, which increases the concentration
of hemoglobin. Over the next two weeks, your hemoglobin
levels will continue to rise, allowing your blood to carry 
even more oxygen per milliliter. Paired with your high heart rate, this new hemoglobin-rich blood efficiently
distributes oxygen throughout your body. So much so that the volume of blood 
being pumped with each heartbeat can return to normal levels. Over this same time, your breathing 
also increases even further in a process called 
ventilatory acclimatization. After this several weeks 
of extended acclimatization, your body has made enough significant
changes to climb even higher. However, you’ll still have to spend
additional time acclimating along the way, often climbing back down to recover 
before ascending even higher. Because the summit of Everest
isn't just high, it’s the highest place on Earth. And at altitudes above 3,500 meters, 
our bodies are under incredible stress. Arteries and veins in the brain
dilate to speed up blood flow, But our smallest blood vessels,
called capillaries, remain the same size. This increased pressure can cause
blood vessels to leak, and fluid to build up in the brain. A similar issue can occur in the lungs, where low oxygen causes blood vessels 
to constrict, leading to more leaking vessels
and fluid buildup. These two conditions— 
known as HACE and HAPE, respectively— are incredibly rare, but can be life-threatening 
if not dealt with quickly. Some Tibetans and South Americans 
with family histories of living at high altitude have genetic advantages that can 
prevent minor altitude sickness, but even they aren’t immune
to these severe conditions. Yet despite these risks, 
climbers over the last century have proved people can go higher 
than scientists ever thought possible. Pushing past their body’s limitations, these climbers have redefined
what humanity can adapt to.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After several weeks of living at high altitude your hemoglobin levels are:
Options: A. Reduced, making more room for oxygen to bind, B. Increased, allowing your blood to carry more oxygen, C. Unchanged, because your heart is beating faster, D. None of the above
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate barometric pressure at the top of Mt. Everest compared to sea level? Options: A. 50%, B. 33%, C. 25%, D. 10% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What happens to the oxygen levels in the air as altitude increases? Options: A. The relative amounts of oxygen increase, B. The relative amounts of oxygen remain the same, but overall oxygen levels decrease, C. The relative amounts of oxygen decrease, D. The relative amounts of oxygen remain the same, and overall oxygen levels increase Correct Option: B
Question 3: A person is planning to climb a mountain with an altitude of 3,000 meters. What advice would you give them to avoid altitude sickness? Options: A. Ascend to the summit as quickly as possible, B. Ascend gradually, taking several weeks to acclimate to the high altitude, C. Stay at sea level for a month before ascending, D. Take medication to prevent altitude sickness Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary function of carotid chemoreceptors in the neck when sensing low oxygen pressure at high altitudes? Options: A. To decrease heart rate and breathing rate, B. To increase heart rate and breathing rate, C. To maintain normal heart rate and breathing rate, D. To decrease blood pressure Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the result of the decrease in plasma volume in the blood after several days at high altitude? Options: A. Decreased concentration of hemoglobin, B. Increased concentration of hemoglobin, C. No change in hemoglobin concentration, D. Decreased heart rate Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the condition that occurs when fluid builds up in the brain due to increased pressure at high altitudes? Options: A. HAPE, B. HACE, C. AMS, D. Hypoxia Correct Option: B
Question 7: Analyze the relationship between altitude and oxygen levels in the air. How do these factors impact the human body? Options: A. As altitude increases, oxygen levels decrease, leading to increased heart rate and breathing rate, B. As altitude increases, oxygen levels increase, leading to decreased heart rate and breathing rate, C. As altitude increases, oxygen levels remain the same, leading to no changes in heart rate and breathing rate, D. As altitude decreases, oxygen levels decrease, leading to increased heart rate and breathing rate Correct Option: A
Question 8: What can be inferred about the genetic advantages of Tibetans and South Americans who have lived at high altitudes for generations? Options: A. They are immune to all forms of altitude sickness, B. They are more susceptible to severe altitude sickness, C. They have a lower risk of minor altitude sickness, but are not immune to severe conditions, D. They have no genetic advantages related to high altitude adaptation Correct Option: C
Question 9: Evaluate the risks and benefits of climbing to extreme altitudes. What can be concluded about human adaptation to high altitudes? Options: A. Humans are not capable of adapting to high altitudes and should avoid climbing to extreme elevations, B. Humans can adapt to high altitudes, but only with extensive training and acclimatization, C. Humans can adapt to high altitudes, and with proper acclimatization, can climb to extreme elevations with minimal risk, D. Humans are naturally adapted to high altitudes and do not require acclimatization Correct Option: C
Question 10: Synthesize the information about high altitude adaptation and propose a plan for a climber to ascend to the summit of Mt. Everest safely. Options: A. Ascend to the summit in one day, taking regular breaks to rest and acclimate, B. Ascend to the summit over the course of several weeks, taking time to acclimate to each new altitude, C. Ascend to the summit in a few days, using medication to prevent altitude sickness, D. Ascend to the summit alone, without any prior experience or acclimatization Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If someone teleported from sea level
to the top of Mt. Everest, things would go bad fast. At an altitude of 8,848 meters, barometric pressure is approximately
33% of what it is at sea level. This means there's significantly
less oxygen in the air, and our teleported individual would
likely suffocate in minutes. However, for people that make this same
journey over the course of a month, it's possible to survive
at the peak for hours. So what can happen to our bodies 
in just one month that allows us to endure
this incredible altitude? Let’s imagine you’re one 
of the 5.8 billion people living less than 500 meters 
above sea level. When you take a breath at this altitude, your lungs fill up with air composed
of numerous gases and compounds. Most important among these 
are oxygen molecules, which bind to the hemoglobin 
in your red blood cells. Blood then circulates 
throughout your body, bringing essential oxygen
to all your cells. But as altitude increases, 
the air starts to get thinner. The relative amounts of each compound
remain the same well into the upper atmosphere, but overall, there is less oxygen 
for our bodies to absorb. And if you ascend to altitudes
above 2,500 meters, the resulting oxygen deprivation can cause
a form of altitude sickness known as AMS, often causing headaches,
fatigue and nausea. Fortunately, AMS only happens
when we ascend too fast, because our bodies have numerous ways
of adapting to high altitudes. Within minutes or even seconds 
of reaching altitudes of 1,500 meters, carotid chemoreceptors in your neck
sense your blood’s low oxygen pressure. This triggers a response that increases 
the rate and depth of your breathing to counteract the lack of oxygen. Your heart rate also increases and your heart contracts more tightly 
to pump additional blood with each beat, quickly moving oxygenated
blood around your body. All these changes happen relatively fast,
and if you were to keep ascending, your heart rate and breathing
would speed up accordingly. But if you stayed at this altitude
for several weeks, you could reap the benefits 
of some longer-term adaptations. Within the first few days 
above 1,500 meters, the volume of plasma 
in your blood decreases, which increases the concentration
of hemoglobin. Over the next two weeks, your hemoglobin
levels will continue to rise, allowing your blood to carry 
even more oxygen per milliliter. Paired with your high heart rate, this new hemoglobin-rich blood efficiently
distributes oxygen throughout your body. So much so that the volume of blood 
being pumped with each heartbeat can return to normal levels. Over this same time, your breathing 
also increases even further in a process called 
ventilatory acclimatization. After this several weeks 
of extended acclimatization, your body has made enough significant
changes to climb even higher. However, you’ll still have to spend
additional time acclimating along the way, often climbing back down to recover 
before ascending even higher. Because the summit of Everest
isn't just high, it’s the highest place on Earth. And at altitudes above 3,500 meters, 
our bodies are under incredible stress. Arteries and veins in the brain
dilate to speed up blood flow, But our smallest blood vessels,
called capillaries, remain the same size. This increased pressure can cause
blood vessels to leak, and fluid to build up in the brain. A similar issue can occur in the lungs, where low oxygen causes blood vessels 
to constrict, leading to more leaking vessels
and fluid buildup. These two conditions— 
known as HACE and HAPE, respectively— are incredibly rare, but can be life-threatening 
if not dealt with quickly. Some Tibetans and South Americans 
with family histories of living at high altitude have genetic advantages that can 
prevent minor altitude sickness, but even they aren’t immune
to these severe conditions. Yet despite these risks, 
climbers over the last century have proved people can go higher 
than scientists ever thought possible. Pushing past their body’s limitations, these climbers have redefined
what humanity can adapt to.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Excessively high pressures inside of blood vessels in the lungs can lead to what high altitude illness?
Options: A. HACE – High altitude cerebral edema, B. AMS – Acute mountain sickness, C. CMS – Chronic mountain sickness, D. HAPE – High altitude pulmonary edema
Correct Option: D
